row.entry: These rules outline the basic requirements for service of originating process and affidavits.

This rules set out the permissible modes of serving court documents. They contain specific provisions relating to service by agreement and by the court. They also provide for service on persons using business names, persons under incapacity, service on solicitors and substituted service.

This Division sets out the circumstances in which personal service of documents is required and regulates the methods of personal service. It includes provision for service on corporations, judicial officers, correctional facilities and other persons.

This Part applies to all courts in Sch 1 of the CPA: see UCPR r 1.5 and Sch 1. This part (other than rr 10.7 and 10.16) applies to the criminal proceedings in the Third Schedule to the Supreme Court Act and to Div 2 of Pt 75 of the SCR (summary jurisdiction): see SCR Pt 75 r 3. This Part (other than rr 10.7 and 10.16) applies to service of a notice of listing under cl 10(2) of the Criminal Procedure Regulation 1987.
The Part is based on the former SCR Pts 9 and 64; DCR Pt 8; and LCR Pt 7. They are supplemented in minor respects by the rules in Pt 3 relating to Electronic Case Management.
Bring to the notice of the person to be served ‥ [10.14.20]
Commencement of proceedings using a business name ‥ [10.9.5]
Deemed service — the effect of a notice of appearance ‥ [10.19.5]
Document not accepted by the person served ‥ [10.21.10]
Legal incapacity, service on person under ‥ [r 10.12] , [10.12.5]
Operation of Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 ‥ [r 10.4]
“Originating process” in the Supreme and District Courts ‥ [10.20.5]
Other documents where personal service required ‥ [10.20.10]
Personal service — acceptance by the person served ‥ [10.21.5]
Service in the precincts of the court ‥ [10.5.10]
Service of process on partner in limited partnership ‥ [r 10.11]
Service where receipt not in issue ‥ [10.5.25]
Steps taken otherwise than under an order under this rule ‥ [10.14.30]
The place where the “business is carried on” ‥ [10.9.10]
Time of service — service on Sunday ‥ [10.5.15]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.1] r 10.1 Service of filed documents (cf SCR Part 15, rule 28)

leg:heading.title: Service of filed documents (cf SCR Part 15, rule 28)

p.text: Unless the court orders otherwise, a party that files a document must as soon as practicable serve copies of the document on each other active party.

In the case of proceedings in the Local Court, an originating process may, and a defence must, be served on the other parties, on behalf of the party by whom it was filed, by an officer of the Local Court.
See rules 10.7 and 10.8 as to how service is to be effected by a court.
[subr (2) am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[1], effective 6 July 2009]

Despite subrule (2), a defence that is filed in proceedings in the Local Court by means of the ECM system (within the meaning of Part 3 ) must be served on the other parties by the party that filed the defence rather than by an officer of the Local Court.
[subr (3) insrt Amendment 35 of 2010 r 3, effective 10 September 2010]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.2] r 10.2 Service of affidavits (cf SCR Part 38, rule 7; DCR Part 30, rule 7; LCR Part 25, rule 7)

leg:heading.title: Service of affidavits (cf SCR Part 38, rule 7; DCR Part 30, rule 7; LCR Part 25, rule 7)

p.text: A party intending to use an affidavit that has not been filed must serve it on each other interested party not later than a reasonable time before the occasion for using it arises.
A party who fails to serve an affidavit as required by subrule (1) may not use the affidavit except by leave of the court.

The period that will constitute a reasonable time for service of an affidavit necessarily depends on the circumstances. A lengthy affidavit, especially one dealing with controversial or complex matters, served a day or so before the hearing, will usually provide good grounds for objection: cf Ex parte Hopwood (1850) 15 QB 121; 117 ER 404 , where service of a summons the day before the hearing was held reasonable and Re Williams (1851) 21 LJMC 46, where the contrary result was reached. See also R v Smith (1875) LR 10 QB 604 (two days insufficient). The court may use the time allotted to hear other evidence in the case before dealing with any application for leave relating to the late service of affidavits: Coulthard v Le Boursicot (NSWSC, McLelland CJ in Eq, No 2738/94, 21 August 1995, unreported, BC9505292).
Legislation cited in [10.2.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 56 and 58.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 2.

Various provisions of the Civil Procedure Act, the Rules and Practice Notes permit directions being made for parties to file and serve affidavit evidence and witness statements on which they intend to rely. Failure to comply with directions of this kind may result in a party being unable to adduce the relevant evidence at the trial of the proceedings: State Pollution Control Commission v Australian Iron & Steel Pty Ltd (No 2) (1992) 29 NSWLR 487; 75 LGERA 327; BC9203134 ; Bomanite Pty Ltd v Slatex Corp Australia Pty Ltd (1991) 32 FCR 379; 104 ALR 165 . See further the notes to CPA ss 56 and 58 and UCPR Pt 2 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.3] r 10.3 Service of originating process in Australia (cf SCR Part 10, rule 2B)

leg:heading.title: Service of originating process in Australia (cf SCR Part 10, rule 2B)

p.text: This rule applies to proceedings in the Supreme Court.
Subject to this Part, originating process may be served anywhere in Australia, whether in New South Wales or elsewhere.

An originating process for service in Australia, but outside New South Wales, must bear a statement either that the plaintiff intends to proceed under the Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 of the Commonwealth or that the plaintiff intends to proceed under the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005.
The plaintiff may proceed otherwise than in accordance with the intention stated under subrule (3), but only with the leave of the court.
Legislation cited in [10.3.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 10.3(3), (4), r 10.4.

The provisions of rr 10.3(3) and (4) nominally require the plaintiff to choose whether to proceed under these rules or the Service and Execution of Process Act 1901 (Cth). The validity of that requirement was upheld in Seymour Smith v Electricity Trust of South Australia (1989) 17 NSWLR 648 . Under a previous version of the Supreme Court Rules, the majority of the High Court held a plaintiff need not choose between the two, and could rely on both: Flaherty v Girgis (1987) 162 CLR 574; 71 ALR 1; BC8701775 .

Despite the wording of rr 10.3(3) and (4), it is doubtful if any election can properly be either made or required. This is because apart from the permission granted by subr (2), the rules no longer provide specifically for interstate service. Service elsewhere in Australia may be effected under the Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 (Cth) and as r 10.4 declares, nothing in the present Part affects the operation of that legislation.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.4] r 10.4 Operation of Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 of the Commonwealth (cf SCR Part 9, rule 1A)

leg:heading.title: Operation of Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 of the Commonwealth (cf SCR Part 9, rule 1A)

p.text: This Part does not limit the operation of the Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 of the Commonwealth or any other law of the Commonwealth.
